Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: The grandmother notices her grandchild seems to be feeling lost or discouraged about a personal matter.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: This evening, as I prepared to light the lamp at our home altar, the familiar scent of sandalwood filled the air. My hands moved automatically, arranging the flowers and incense, but my mind was elsewhere. Just moments before, I had seen my granddaughter sitting alone on the veranda, her shoulders slumped, eyes distant. I could sense her sadness, the way only a grandmother can. My heart ached to go to her, to offer the comfort and wisdom I have gathered over a lifetime. Yet, the time for my daily prayers had arrived—a sacred duty I have never neglected, a practice that grounds me in my faith and connects me to the divine. I stood torn, the lamp in my hand trembling slightly. Should I pause my ritual, breaking a tradition I hold dear, or should I trust that my granddaughter will find her way, just as I must honor my own path? The weight of both roles pressed upon me, each demanding my presence, each pulling me in a different direction.
